overview.problemStatement:

A number $n$ is highly composite if $\tau(m)<\tau(n)$ for all $m<n$, where $\tau(m)$ counts the number of divisors of $m$. Let $Q(x)$ count the number of highly composite numbers in $[1,x]$.

Is it true that\[Q(x)\gg_k (\log x)^k\]for every $k\geq 1$?



Erd\H{o}s \cite{Er44} proved $Q(x)\gg (\log x)^{1+c}$ for some constant $c>0$.

The answer to this problem is no: Nicolas \cite{Ni71} proved that\[Q(x) \ll (\log x)^{O(1)}.\]




References


[Er44] Erd\H{o}s, P., On highly composite numbers. J. London Math. Soc. (1944), 130-133.

[Ni71] Nicolas, Jean-Louis, R\'{e}partition des nombres hautement compos\'{e}s de Ramanujan. Canadian J. Math. (1971), 116-130.
